instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_LCD: What is PP3V3_S5_LCD? PP3V3_S5_LCD is a power rail that eventually powers circuitry in the LCD after going through something else. This is required for the LCD to turn on and have a nimage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Hey guys, I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no image.
[LIST]
[*]External monitor DOES work.
[*]The image is not dim, it is non-existent.
[*]Tried 3 different displays and eDP cables.
[/LIST]
With display connected:
[LIST]
[*]<SIGNAL>LCD_IRQ_L</SIGNAL>  - 10.00 mV
[*]<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> - 10.00 mV
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_LCD</SIGNAL> - 5.13 V
[*]<SIGNAL>PANEL_P5V_EN</SIGNAL> - 0 V (checked on test point and <RESISTOR>R8515</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C8515</CAPACITOR>)
[*]<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 0 V
[*]<SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>  - 0 V
[/LIST]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Any history available?
Liquid signs at LCD connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 62429, member: 682"]
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Any history available?
Liquid signs at LCD connector?
[/QUOTE]

Thanks!
No signs of liquid damage. LCD connector looks good. Came in for LCD replacement because of no image and previous LCD was cracked and had no signs of life. New LCD didn't fix the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Check the other LCD connector in the case; where the small flex from MLB gets connected.
Did someone else work on it before?
Check for knocked of components, near the screw areas.

Please, do NOT quote an entire post visible few centimeters above.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
It looks like it has been worked on before. 
<DIODE>D8518</DIODE> near <CHIP>U8501</CHIP> was knocked off but I replaced. Also replaced <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8501</CHIP> to be safe.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Probably more damage on the board.
You should check all traces and be sure about solders.
We need some voltages on LCD connector (screen connected).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Are you suggesting I check my <CHIP>U8500</CHIP>, <CHIP>U8510</CHIP>, and <DIODE>D8518</DIODE> solders?
I did do a thorough inspection on the board and I see no other places that seem to have been tampered. I do notice the area around L2990 gets a bit hot but can't find a short and voltages are normal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Check diode mode readings for all <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_X</SIGNAL> lines; good to have working board for comparison.

<RESISTOR>R8554</RESISTOR> is good?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message: 0 V on <RESISTOR>R8554</RESISTOR>, diode readings for all  <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_X</SIGNAL> lines is OL.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Recheck puting red probe to ground; and remember this, when you check diode mode!
And check w/ and w/o LCD connected.

"0 V on <RESISTOR>R8554</RESISTOR>"
I just asked if resistor is good, as ohm value.
You said 0V and no idea which pin you've measured.
A bad resistor can have correct voltage on one pin and 0V on other...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R8554</RESISTOR> is 0 ohms.
Diode reading were tested with red probe on ground.
Everything  <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_X</SIGNAL> is OL

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
I just saw this board has separation caps; so correct OL values.
In sthis case, the caps also protect against overvoltage on LCD connector.

"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_LCD</SIGNAL> - 5.13 V"
Are you sure about this?

Check if you get at least a pulse at <SIGNAL>PANEL_P3V3_EN</SIGNAL> in the first seconds, when board boots.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
5.13 was an error. It's 3.32.
I do get a quick pulse in the first 10 seconds on  <SIGNAL>PANEL_P3V3_EN</SIGNAL> 3.35v. Tested at <CAPACITOR>C8516</CAPACITOR> pin1 and <RESISTOR>R8590</RESISTOR> pin1.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
You should get corresponding voltage at pins 44/45 of J8300 at same time; confirm that.
If yes, <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> must pulse too; LCD connected, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message: 45 gets a pulse at 5v but 44 gets nothing. <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> gets nothing. <RESISTOR>R8501</RESISTOR> ohms was low so I replaced. Still nothing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8500</CHIP>/01 are both enabled by the same signal.
Compare reactions at their pins.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5_LCD</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Ok, just got 45 and 44 to pulse at 5v and 3v respectively.
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5_LCD</SIGNAL> is 3.3
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> pulses at .800V at first few seconds.
<SIGNAL>PANEL_P3V3_EN</SIGNAL> pulse at 3.35v
<SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>  pulse at 3.35v
<SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> pulse at .800v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
You should test with an o-scope, it can show exact peak pulse value.
If <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> pulse to 3V, means LCD replies correctly; PCH should recognize its presence.

Be sure <SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> also has 3V peak pulse.
If not, change <CHIP>U8510</CHIP>.
